hints_html:
The right hand Riemann sum is computed by

\(R_{n} = \sum_{i=1}^{n}f(x_{i})\Delta x\)

whereas the left hand Riemann sum is computed by

\(L_{n} = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1}f(x_{i})\Delta x\)

What happens when you subtract these two values?
hints_latex:
The right hand Riemann sum is computed by

$R_{n} = \sum_{i=1}^{n}f(x_{i})\Delta x$

whereas the left hand Riemann sum is computed by

$L_{n} = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1}f(x_{i})\Delta x$

What happens when you subtract these two values?
hints_raw:
The right hand Riemann sum is computed by

<math>
R_{n} = \sum_{i=1}^{n}f(x_{i})\Delta x
</math>

whereas the left hand Riemann sum is computed by

<math>
L_{n} = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1}f(x_{i})\Delta x
</math>

What happens when you subtract these two values?
question: 8 (a)
sols_html:
The right hand Riemann sum is computed by

\(R_{100} = \sum_{i=1}^{100}f(x_{i})\Delta x\)

whereas the left hand Riemann sum is computed by

\(L_{100} = \sum_{i=0}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x\)

and hence, we have

\[\begin{aligned} R_{100} - L_{100} &= \sum_{i=1}^{100}f(x_{i})\Delta x - \sum_{i=0}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x \\ &= f(x_{100})\Delta x + \sum_{i=1}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x - \sum_{i=1}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x - f(x_{0})\Delta x \\ &= f(4)\Delta x - f(0)\Delta x \\ &= 8\Delta x - (0)\Delta x \\ &= 8\Delta x \end{aligned}\]

By definition, we know

\(\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-0}{100} = \frac{1}{25}\)

and so

\[\begin{aligned} R_{100} - L_{100} = 8\Delta x = \frac{8}{25}\end{aligned}\]

completing the proof.
sols_latex:
The right hand Riemann sum is computed by

$R_{100} = \sum_{i=1}^{100}f(x_{i})\Delta x$

whereas the left hand Riemann sum is computed by

$L_{100} = \sum_{i=0}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x$

and hence, we have

\begin{align*}
R_{100} - L_{100} &= \sum_{i=1}^{100}f(x_{i})\Delta x - \sum_{i=0}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x \\
&= f(x_{100})\Delta x + \sum_{i=1}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x - \sum_{i=1}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x - f(x_{0})\Delta x \\
&= f(4)\Delta x  - f(0)\Delta x \\
&= 8\Delta x  - (0)\Delta x \\
&= 8\Delta x 
\end{align*}

By definition, we know

$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-0}{100} = \frac{1}{25}$

and so

\begin{align*}
R_{100} - L_{100} = 8\Delta x = \frac{8}{25}
\end{align*}

completing the proof.
sols_raw:
The right hand Riemann sum is computed by

<math>
R_{100} = \sum_{i=1}^{100}f(x_{i})\Delta x
</math>

whereas the left hand Riemann sum is computed by

<math>
L_{100} = \sum_{i=0}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x
</math>

and hence, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
R_{100} - L_{100} &= \sum_{i=1}^{100}f(x_{i})\Delta x - \sum_{i=0}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x \\
&= f(x_{100})\Delta x + \sum_{i=1}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x - \sum_{i=1}^{99}f(x_{i})\Delta x - f(x_{0})\Delta x \\
&= f(4)\Delta x  - f(0)\Delta x \\
&= 8\Delta x  - (0)\Delta x \\
&= 8\Delta x 
\end{align}
</math>

By definition, we know

<math>
\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{4-0}{100} = \frac{1}{25}
</math>

and so 

<math>
\begin{align}
R_{100} - L_{100} = 8\Delta x = \frac{8}{25}
\end{align}
</math>

completing the proof.
statement_html:
An unknown continuous function \(f(x)\) satisfies \(f(0)=0\), \(f(4) = 8\), and

\[\begin{aligned} 2x \leq f(x) \leq 6x-x^2\end{aligned}\]

for \(0 \leq x \leq 4.\) Also, \(f(x)\) is nondecreasing on this interval, i.e. it satisfies \(f(c)\leq f(d)\) for all real numbers \(c\) and \(d\) with \(0 \leq c \leq d \leq 4.\) Let \(I\) be the value of definite integral \(\int_0^4 f(x)\,dx.\)

(a) Let \(L_{100}\) be the underestimate for \(I\) obtained by using a Riemann sum with equal-length subintervals and \(x_i^* = x_{i-1}\) (i.e. using the left endpoints of the subintervals), and \(R_{100}\) be the overestimate obtained by using \(x_i^* = x_i\) (i.e. the right endpoints). Compute a numerical value for \(R_{100}-L_{100}\).
statement_latex:
An unknown continuous function $f(x)$ satisfies $f(0)=0$, $f(4) = 8$,
and

\begin{align*}
2x \leq f(x) \leq 6x-x^2
\end{align*}

for $0 \leq x \leq 4.$ Also, $f(x)$ is \emph{nondecreasing} on this
interval, i.e. it satisfies $f(c)\leq f(d)$ for all real numbers $c$ and
$d$ with $0 \leq c \leq d \leq 4.$ Let $I$ be the value of definite
integral $\int_0^4 f(x)\,dx.$

(a) Let $L_{100}$ be the underestimate for $I$ obtained by using a
Riemann sum with equal-length subintervals and $x_i^* = x_{i-1}$ (i.e.
using the left endpoints of the subintervals), and $R_{100}$ be the
overestimate obtained by using $x_i^* = x_i$ (i.e. the right endpoints).
Compute a numerical value for $R_{100}-L_{100}$.
statement_raw:
An unknown continuous function <math>f(x)</math> satisfies <math>f(0)=0</math>, <math>f(4) = 8</math>, and

:<math> 2x \leq f(x) \leq 6x-x^2 </math>

for <math> 0 \leq x \leq 4.</math> Also, <math>f(x)</math> is ''nondecreasing'' on this interval, i.e. it satisfies <math>f(c)\leq f(d)</math> for all real numbers <math>c</math> and <math>d</math> with <math>0 \leq c \leq d \leq 4.</math> Let <math>I</math> be the value of definite integral <math>\int_0^4 f(x)\,dx.</math>

(a) Let <math>L_{100}</math> be the underestimate for <math>I</math> obtained by using a Riemann sum with equal-length subintervals and <math>x_i^* = x_{i-1}</math> (i.e. using the left endpoints of the subintervals), and <math>R_{100}</math> be the overestimate obtained by using <math>x_i^* = x_i</math> (i.e. the right endpoints). Compute a numerical value for <math>R_{100}-L_{100}</math>.
